author: tokey1475
content: Given the ropsten shenanigans should we be concerned about gas limits being used as an attack vector on mainnet?  Very low is obviously bad for users and very high sounds like it could cause issues for the CL per <@755590043632140352>

author: timbeiko
content: I personally would like us to have an in-protocol cap like <@543900561460822016> proposed a while back. On mainnet, it's not really economical for validators to reduce the gas limit given they get less txn fees.

author: potuz
content: I don't think this is a big issue in itself, I just would want to have realistic, as close as mainnet as possible, testing before shipping the merge.

author: tokey1475
content: I wonder if miners might do ok with quite low gas limits, since users who wanted to get included would have to pay large priority fees

author: tokey1475
content: that makes sense.  I'm just concerned that there may be a (hopefully small) contingent of miners that will look to push us into whatever edge cases they can find that haven't been tested or prevented

author: potuz
content: To be honest, I'm more worried about validators than miners on that regard ðŸ˜…

author: timbeiko
content: this isn't necessarily the case: if at a given block limit miners make a given $ in priority fees, if you reduce the gas limit, users may pay more, but the total to miners should be roughly the same (more $ per gas * less gas)
